conclusion: To find the change in magnetic flux, apply the formula: Φ = B ⋅ A ⋅ cosθ, where B is the magnetic induction intensity, A is the area of the coil, and θ is the angle between the magnetic field vector and the area vector.
The change in magnetic flux is ΔΦ = Φ_final - Φ_initial.
The coil ABCO is shown in the figure and appears to lie in the xz-plane.
The magnetic field B is in the positive x-direction.
The area of the coil is A = 0.4 m².
The magnetic induction intensity is B = 0.1 T.
Initially, the coil ABCO lies in the xz-plane, and the normal vector to the coil's plane can point either in the positive y-direction or the negative y-direction.
Assume the normal vector is chosen such that the initial flux is positive, so it points in the positive y-direction.
The angle between the positive y-axis and the positive x-axis is 90°.
Therefore, the initial angle θ_initial = 90°.
Calculate the initial magnetic flux Φ_initial = B A cos(θ_initial) = (0.1 T) (0.4 m²) cos(90°) = 0 Wb.
The coil rotates 60° downward around the z-axis.
Rotating 60° downward around the z-axis means the positive y-axis direction of the normal vector moves towards the positive x-axis or negative x-axis.
If the coil rotates downward around the z-axis, its normal vector will rotate towards the x-axis.
The angle of rotation is 60°.
The new angle between the rotated area vector and the y-axis will be 60°.
The angle between the magnetic field and the final normal vector needs to be determined.
After rotating 60° downward around the z-axis, the normal vector will be in the xy-plane, making an angle of 30° with the positive x-axis.
So, θ_final = 30°.
Calculate the final magnetic flux Φ_final = B A cos(θ_final) = (0.1 T) (0.4 m²) cos(30°) = 0.02√3 Wb.
